definition: to muddle through/to fob sb off/to beat around the bush/to dodge
to keep out/to hold off/to ward off/to evade/to spread/to coat/to smear/to daub
Serbia/Serbian/abbr. for 塞爾維亞|塞尔维亚[Sai1 er3 wei2 ya4]
to stop up/to squeeze in/to stuff/cork/stopper
strategic pass/tactical border position
to stop up/to stuff/to cope with

sentences.english: Prevarication is one of the techniques the businessman prefers to employ.
sentences.chinese: 搪塞是这个商人喜欢使用的技巧之一。

sentences.english: I asked her for the dictionary she borrowed from me, but she just fobbed me off with a stupid excuse.
sentences.chinese: 借我的字典还给我，她却胡乱找个借口把我搪塞过去。

sentences.english: Prevarication must not be the name of the game.
sentences.chinese: 而搪塞决不能成为游戏的名字。

sentences.english: To talk or act insincerely or misleadingly; equivocate .
sentences.chinese: 支吾，搪塞不说真话，含糊其词。

sentences.english: He tried to argue away his mistake.
sentences.chinese: 他试图用话把自己的错误搪塞过去。

sentences.english: He had good reason to prevaricate.
sentences.chinese: 他的搪塞之词是有根源的。

sentences.english: Jon just fenced with his criticism and made no real attempt to answer it.
sentences.chinese: 乔恩对他的批评只是搪塞，他并不打算回答它。

sentences.english: All her attempts to question the authorities on the subject have been met by evasion and prevarication.
sentences.chinese: 她就这一问题质问权威的一切尝试均被回避和搪塞。

sentences.english: She would prevaricate, but it would be in the line of her feelings at least.
sentences.chinese: 所以即使掩饰搪塞，她也得找个和她心情一致的借口。

sentences.english: The old priest tried to put them off, saying that the hour was late.
sentences.chinese: 那位老牧师试图把他们搪塞过去，说时候不早了。

sentences.english: Treasury Department must stop fudging and obfuscating.
sentences.chinese: 首先，美国财政部应该停止搪塞和糊弄。

sentences.english: I asked her for the money she owed me, but she just fobbed me off with a stupid excuse.
sentences.chinese: 我向她讨还欠款，她却胡乱找个借口把我搪塞过去。

sentences.english: A little overwhelmed, I began the generalized evasions which that question deserves.
sentences.chinese: 我有点不知所措，就开始说一些含糊其词的话来搪塞。

sentences.english: He managed to stall off his creditor.
sentences.chinese: 他设法把债主搪塞过去了。

sentences.english: But France is always dragging, and finally even quoted "day price" to prevaricate.
sentences.chinese: 但法方总是百般拖延，最后甚至报出“天价”来搪塞。

sentences.english: He accused the minister of prevaricating.
sentences.chinese: 他指责部长用搪塞蒙混过关。

definition: to make excuses/to give an excuse (for not doing something)
to make an excuse/pretext/excuse
to evade/to shirk
to use as an excuse/on the pretext/excuse/pretext
to deceive/to hoodwink/Taiwan pr. [meng1 hun4]
to elaborate (on a theme)/to expound (the classics)/perfunctory/to skimp/to botch/to do sth half-heartedly or just for show/barely enough to get by
see 託詞|托词[tuo1 ci2]
see 託詞|托词[tuo1 ci2]
to equivocate/to talk evasively (idiom)
high-sounding/dignified/pompous (idiom)
to fool/to deceive/to go through the motions
to avoid the important and dwell on the trivial/to keep silent about major charges while admitting minor ones
to decline/to avoid/shirking responsibilities/to blame others/to pass the buck/to unload one's responsibilities/to try to get out of a task
lie
to deceive/to cheat
to look for a pretext
to joke/to laugh insincerely/to make merry/to talk irrelevantly
